Graphical abstract Cobalt (Co) nanoparticles anchored porous N-doped carbon nanosheets (Co@PNCS) were fabricated using a facile one-pot pyrolysis route and tested as high-performance cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries. The hierarchical structure was made of cobalt nanoparticles distributed in the crumpled porous carbon nanosheets. Uniformly distributed and exposed cobalt nanoparticles in the PNCS exhibited a higher electrocatalytic activity compared to Co nanoparticles anchored nitrogen-carbon materials (Co-N-C). Density function theory (DFT) calculations based on the interfacial model demonstrated that the active Co sites exhibited a more stable binding ability to discharge Li2O2 products than that of the active N sites, and Li2O2 could be reversibly formed and decomposed during cycling. Owing to optimal loadings of Co nanoparticles (16.03 wt%), the Co@PNCS-2 cathode exhibited a high specific capacity of 11,329 mAh g−1 and extended cycling life of 120 cycles, highlighting the great potential as cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries. Keywords N-doped carbon nanosheets Li-O2 batteries High capacity Stability Cobalt 1 Introduction Li-O2 batteries can deliver an extremely high theoretical energy density of about 3600 Wh Kg−1, yielding nearly 10 times larger than conventional Li-ion batteries [1,2], and thus have been an appealing energy storage system for portable electronics and electric vehicles. However, challenges facing their practical implementations include limited specific capacity, inferior rate capability, low round trip energy efficiency and poor cycling stability, etc [3,4]. Li-O2 batteries are restricted by the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) involving the formation of Li2O2 and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) involving the reversible decomposition of Li2O2 during cycling [5–7]. Cathode catalysts with well-designed structures have been claimed to boost sluggish ORR and OER during charge/discharge [8,9]. Therefore, the development of efficient cathode catalysts is vital [10–12]. Tremendous efforts have been made to explore better-performing catalysts, such as porous carbon [13,14], precious metal [15,16], metal alloy [17,18], metal oxide [19,20], metal nitride [21,22] and metal carbide [23,24]. Amongst them, C-supported Pt-group metals (such as Pt, Ru, Pd, and Ir) have been regarded as ideal cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries, effectively catalyzing the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 [25–27]. Carbon materials as three-dimensional matrixes have large specific surface areas, stable structures and high electrical conductivity [28]. N-doping into carbons could further enhance their electrical conductivity and provide more active sites for the catalytic reactions. The subsequent electron cloud distribution change of carbon materials caused by N-doping could coordinate the dimensions and dispersion of the metal particles, utilizing their full potential as active reaction sites [29,30]. The employment of Pt-group metals has been limited due to their scarcity and high cost, restricting their commercial applications in Li-O2 batteries [31]. Recently, carbon-supported transition metal (metal = Co, Fe, Ni, etc.) [32–35] have attracted intense attention owing to their large specific surface area, high porosity, high conductivity and sufficient active sites [36–39], being the prospective cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries. For example, Zhou et al. utilized a sol-gel process to prepare Co nanoparticles dispersed on carbon substrates, yielding a discharge specific capacity of 5000 mAh g−1 at 0.3 A g−1 and operating for 80 cycles at 0.2 A g−1 with a capacity of 600 mAh g−1 [40]. A mixture of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O and polyaniline had been investigated by Kim et al. to synthesize the Co embedded carbon nanofibers (CNFs) by an electrospinning route, and the cathode exhibited a cycling performance of about 70 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 with the cut-off capacity of 500 mAh g−1 [41]. Cao et al. reported that Co encapsulated porous CNFs synthesized through an electrospinning method, delivering a cycle life of about 50 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 with a cut-off capacity of 500 mAh g−1 [42]. The fabricated Co decorated single-layer graphene sheet by Bao et al. achieved a discharge specific capacity of nearly 7000 mAh g−1 and was reversibly discharged and charged for about 100 cycles at 0.2 A g−1 with a cut-off capacity of 600 mAh g−1 [38]. Although the reported Co decorated N-doped carbon catalysts had achieved favorable performance, most synthetic methods involved multiple steps and high temperature and/or expensive reactants, causing high energy losses and environmental pollution. It is thus highly desirable to synthesize highly active and low-cost Co decorated N-doped carbon cathode catalysts in a simple and clean way on a large scale. On the other hand, to date, there is no report on the deep investigation of reaction mechanisms of the Co decorated N-doped carbon catalysts for Li-O2 batteries, including those related to the formation and adsorption of LiO2 and Li2O2 on their surfaces theoretically. These actually play important roles in the Li-O2 battery performance of the cathode catalysts. It is thus to deliver the cost-effective, eco-friendly synthesis and to unravel the reaction mechanisms that constitute the focus of this work. In this work, cobalt anchored porous N-doped carbon nanosheets (Co@PNCS) were synthesized by a cost-effective one-pot method and their feasibility serving as cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries was tested. A unique structure was created with Co nanoparticles homogeneously distributed into the PNCS. The incorporation of Co nanoparticles were highly active for the adsorption of Li2O2 species, which was confirmed by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The Co@PNCS cathodes could remarkably promote both ORR and OER electrocatalytic activity spontaneously, contributing to superior specific capacity, high rate capability and good cyclability, which remarkably boosted the practical application of Li-O2 batteries. DFT calculations were also conducted to elucidate the excellent electrocatalytic performance, providing a profound understanding the role of active sites playing in the discharge-charge processes. Eventually, a mechanism for the electrocatalysis occurring herein was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation To prepare the Co@PNCS catalysts, 10 g urea, 0.5 g glucose and the defined amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O were added into 80 mL distilled water and allowed to react at 60 °C under stirring until distilled water was evaporated. The crucible with precursor was heated to 800 °C at a speed of 3 °C min−1 for 2.5 h in a N2 atmosphere. The Co@PNCS catalysts were obtained after removing ORR unstable phases by washing the as-prepared materials with 0.5 M H2SO4 at 80 °C overnight and with deionized water several times at room temperature. The amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O used as reactants in the preparation process was 0.05, 0.1 and 0.15 g, and the resulting composites were designated as Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3, respectively. PNCS were also compounded by the same way without any addition of Co (NO3)2·6H2O. 2.2 Characterizations X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were investigated by an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-r B) using Cu Ka radiation. The morphology of the materials was examined using a field-emission scanning microscope (FESEM, SU-70) furnished with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves were tested with a Micrometritics analyzer (ASAP 2020) to confirm the specific surface area and the porosity. Raman spectra were collected by a Bruker spectrometer (RFS 100/S). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted in air using a Theremogravimetric analyer (TGA/SDTA851e). The XPS data was achieved on a Vacuum Generator Scientific spectrometer (ESCA 2000) and all the results were calibrated by C 1s = 284.6 eV. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements 80 wt% Co@PNCS composites and 20 wt% poly (tetrafluoroethylene) were ultrasonically mixed in isopropanol. They were then dropped onto the Toray carbon paper (TGP-H-060), and the cathodes were vacuum dried at 120 °C overnight. The typical catalyst loading for one cathode slice was 0.4–0.5 mg. CR 2032 coin-type cells with holes in their positive top covers were used to investigate the electrocatalytic property. The cell was assembled inside a glovebox under an Ar atmosphere (H2O < 0.1 ppm, O2 < 0.1 ppm) using the catalyst-containing cathode and the Li foil anode, separated by the glassy fiber separator soaking with 1 M LiCF3SO3-TEGDME electrolyte. The cycling voltammetry (CV) measurements were tested on an electrochemical workstation ((RST5002F) at 0.1 mV s−1 between 2.35 and 4.35 V versus Li/Li+. Galvanostatic discharge-charge tests were launched on a LAND battery tester (LANHE CT2001A). The current densities and specific capacities were calculated based on the total amount of the catalysts. All battery measurements were examined at room temperature and in a high-purity oxygen atmosphere. 2.4 DFT calculations The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were obtained by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [43] with the projector-augmented wave (PAW) [44]. All calculations were under the same generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [45] along with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) for the exchange-correlation term. The cutoff of the plane-wave kinetic energy was 400 eV. Γ-centered 11 × 11 × 11, 9 × 9 × 1, and 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh was used for the geometry optimization of bulk system, Co (1 1 1) surface, and PNCS (Graphitic-N1, Graphitic-N2, Pyridinic-N and Pyrrolic-N) systems, respectively. A vacuum gap of 15 Å was set in the direction perpendicular to the surface. A Co (1 1 1) four-layer slab modelled by a 2 × 2 supercell was used to investigate the interaction energies between LiO2, Li2O2 monomer and exposed Co (1 1 1) planes [46,47]. The unit box with a volume of 12.29 Å × 21.30 Å × 15.00 Å was built for PNCS to investigate the interaction energies between LiO2, Li2O2 monomer and PNCS. The adsorption energy (Eads) for LixO2 molecule on the catalyst surface is defined as: E b i n d i n g = E L i X O 2 / s u r f a c e - E L i X O 2 - E s u r f a c e where the E L i X O 2 / s u r f a c e , E L i X O 2 and E s u r f a c e represent the DFT total energies of the surface with the absorbed LixO2 monomer, isolated LixO2 monomer, and relaxed surface structure, respectively 3 Results and discussion The Co@PNCS catalysts were synthesized via a one-step pyrolysis route (Fig. 1 a). A mixture of urea, glucose and Co-containing salts were homogeneously mixed, followed by drying and thermal treatment in a N2 atmosphere. During the pyrolysis process, urea and glucose were transformed into the N-C nanosheets structure, followed by gas (H2O, CO2 and NH3) release, and the pores were in-situ formed on the nanosheets. Contemporaneously, the Co nanoparticles embedded in the nanosheets were covered with graphitic layers at high temperatures. Hierarchical structure was generated with crumpled structure and nanopores in carbon nanosheets. Therefore, the Co@PNCS catalysts were gained. Porous aggregates of the carbon nanosheets can be observed for the PNCS catalyst (Fig. 1b), and similar structure was maintained without any large Co particles for the Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3 catalysts (supporting information, Fig. S1a, b, Fig. 1c), respectively. Green, yellow and red spots in the EDS mapping image (Fig. 1g) revealed the C, N and Co elements in the Co@PNCS-2 catalysts, respectively, indicating the homogeneous distribution of the Co nanoparticles on the PNCS, confirmed by Fig. 1(d and e). Co nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution of 9.85 ± 0.7 nm and small pores with an average size of lower than 5 nm are observed in the Co@PNCS-2 catalysts (Fig. 1d). The lattice spacing of 0.20 nm in the Co nanoparticles corresponds to the (1 1 1) plane of spinel Co [48], and carbon sheet with the lattice spacing of 0.36 nm presents around the Co nanoparticle (Fig. 1f), in agreement with the (0 0 2) plane of the graphitic carbon [49]. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset of Fig. 1f) with the diffraction rings clearly shows (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes of Co, as well as (0 0 2) plane of graphitic carbon, respectively. XRD patterns of PNCS, Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3 presenting a peak at 26.1° illustrate the production of graphitic carbon during the pyrolytic reaction (Fig. 2 a). The diffraction peaks at 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9° are related to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) planes of Co phase (JCPDS, No. 15-0806) [50]. The D band at ∼1357 cm−1 in the Raman spectrum (Fig. 2b) is related to the disorder, defects and amorphous carbon structure, while the G band at ∼1577 cm−1 originates from the stretching motion of sp2 pairs [51]. The intensity ratio of the D and G bands (ID/IG) was determined to evaluate the disorder degree of carbon materials [52,53]. The ID/IG value was slightly decreased with the increase of Co contents in the catalysts, i.e., 1.21, 1.16, 1.12 and 1.08 for PNCS, Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3 catalysts, respectively. It suggests that the graphitization of carbon matrix can be enhanced through the decoration of Co nanoparticles [54,55]. The content of Co nanoparticles in the Co@PNCS catalysts has been analyzed by TGA. After the treatment in air between 20 and 700 °C, carbon in the composite catalysts has been burned off and the resulting product can be identified as Co3O4 [56,57]. Therefore, the Co contents in the Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3 catalysts are approximately to be 12.32, 16.03 and 19.74 wt%, respectively. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm curve of the Co@PNCS-2 catalyst shows the characteristics of the type IV isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loop (Fig S2a), determining the specific surface area of 113.64 cm2 g−1. The Co@PNCS-2 catalyst displays a narrow pore diameter distribution concentrated at 3.59 nm (Fig S2b), and the pores throughout the catalyst should be mainly related to a large amount of NH3 and CO2 gas from decomposing urea and Co(NO3)2·6H2O [58]. High-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum can be deconvoluted into peaks at 285.9 and 284.6 and 285 eV (Fig. 2d), corresponding to the CN and CC and CC bonds, respectively [59]. The relative concentration of CN in C bonds of Co@NG-0.1 composite is 15.5% similar to that of NG through calculating the area of CN peak in the total C region, i.e., 16.1% (Fig. 2d and Fig. S3a). The high-resolution N 1s spectrum can be deconvoluted into the peaks at 405, 400.7 and 398.6 eV (Fig. 2e), representing Graphitic-N, Pyrrolic-N and Pyridinic-N, respectively. Thus, it is concluded that the N atoms were successfully doped into the framework of carbon [60,61]. Some differences in the structures and electrical properties are observed among these reported N-doped carbons. The Pyridinic-N3 is used to refer to the N atoms located in a π conjugated system with one p electron in a six-membered ring, while the Pyrrolic-N3 refers to N atoms contributing to the π system with two p electrons in a five-membered ring [62]. The Graphitic-N1 and Graphitic-N2 correspond to highly coordinated N atoms displacing inner one and two C atoms on the graphite layers, respectively [63]. The high-resolution spectrum of Co 2p exhibits the peaks at 793.8 and 778.7 eV, which are associated with the metallic Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2, respectively (Fig. 2f), and the others at 799.6 and 782 eV are satellite peaks [47,64,65]. The electrochemical performance of Li-O2 battery with different cathodes were summarized in Fig. 3 . The calculated discharge specific capacities of the PNCS, Co@PNCS-1, Co@PNCS-2 and Co@PNCS-3 cathodes are 5730, 7787, 11,329 and 10,627 mAh g−1, respectively. A Li-O2 battery taking merely the carbon paper as electrode materials was also assembled for comparison, and the current and specific capacities were calculated according to the average weight of the catalysts. The specific capacities of the carbon paper are quite low (Fig. S4), indicating a limited benefit to the capacity, and it can serve as the current collector in Li-O2 batteries. The hierarchical porous structure of the PNCS catalysis could not only enable sufficient infiltration of the electrolyte, but also provide enough space for the nucleation and deposition of Li2O2. Moreover, N-doping effectively increased the electrical conductivity of the PNCS catalyst, and the active sites of pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N had boosted the catalytic activity of the carbon-based material, realizing a favorable discharge capacity [29,66]. Notably, the Co@PNCS cathodes deliver remarkably enhanced discharge specific capacities and lower over-potentials compared with that of the PNCS cathode. Since N atoms on PNCS are considered to harmonize the Co particles in the aspect of dimensions and dispersion, Co nanoparticles could be made fully effective for their high catalytic activity. The Co@PNCS-2 cathode thus exhibits the best electrocatalytic property. The Co@PNCS-1 cathode delivers lower specific capacities and higher over-potentials owing to lower loadings of Co nanoparticles, and the inferior electrocatalytic performance of the Co@PNCS-3 cathode could probably be owing to the non-uniform distribution of Co nanoparticles. The optimal Co content in the catalyst is 16.03 wt%. Concerning the rate performance, the Co@PNCS-2 cathode exhibits attractive discharge specific capacities of 6725, 4352 and 2771 mAh g−1 at 200, 400 and 600 mA g−1, respectively (Fig. 3b). To better comprehend the elementary effect of Co-doping on the Li-O2 battery reaction kinetics, the electrode reactions were further investigated by cyclic voltammetry measurements. The CV was obtained at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 between 2.35 and 4.35 V under O2 atmosphere. Compared with that of the PNCS cathode, prominent current signals can be traced for Co@PNCS cathodes, when the potential is reduced to lower than 2.8 V at the cathodic sweep, demonstrating the appearance of Li2O2 as the ORR products [67,68]. In addition, clear broad OER peaks can be scanned in the anodic portion due to the oxidation of Li2O2. These indicate that the Co@PNCS cathodes could deliver a bifunctional catalytic performance during the anodic and cathodic scan processes [69]. The Co@PNCS-2 cathode shows a more positive ORR potential and a more negative OER potential, resulting in lower over-potentials and superior battery efficiency. The selected discharge-charge curves of the PNCS and Co@PNCS-2 cathode materials present that the terminal discharge voltage of the PNCS cathode is decreased to 1.53 V at 60th cycle, and the Co@PNCS-2 cathode remains stable at about 2.32 V over 120 cycles (Fig. 3(d and e)). In the corresponding initial discharge and charge curves (Fig. 3f), the Co@PNCS-2 cathode displays a lower discharge (0.17 V) and charge (1.26 V) over-potential, with a better round-trip performance, which is vital for the cycling stability of the Li-O2 batteries, evidenced by the continuously cycled curves (Fig. 3g). Table S1 lists the Li-O2 battery characteristics of the Co@PNCS cathode versus various Co decorated N-doped carbon cathodes reported in the open literatures. It is proved that the Co@PNCS cathode outperforms most previously reported Co decorated N-doped carbon cathodes under similar testing conditions, making it highly competitive cathode electrocatalysts for Li-O2 batteries. To better clarify the performance of the Li-O2 battery during cycling, EIS measurements were further carried out on the cathodes at different stages (Fig. 4 (a and b)). Typically, the diameter of the semicircle is related to the charge-transfer resistance, and consequently the PNCS cathode shows an increased diameter obviously after 60 cycles, while that of the Co@PNCS-2 cathode changes slightly after 120 cycles, suggesting that the Co@PNCS-2 cathode shows a facilitated charge transport during cycling. It is supposed that PNCS cathode could not sufficiently decompose the insulating discharge products, which has a negative effect on its charge transport and electrocatalytic performance. SEM images were collected to explore the morphological changes of the Co@PNCS-2 cathode after charge/discharge. The film-like structure was observed precipitated on cathode surface at 1st discharged stage (Fig. 4d). After being charged, the solid product on the cathode disappeared, and the sheet-like structure was regained (Fig. 4e). This structure could also be maintained after 120 cycles at a fixed capacity (Fig. 4f), proving the superior stability of the Co@PNCS-2 cathode. The structural evolution of discharge products was further demonstrated by XRD (Fig. 4c). The peaks between 30 and 40° at 1st discharged stage can be indexed to the planes of the Li2O2, demonstrating that the film-like discharge product was mainly composed of crystalline Li2O2. They cannot be traced at the 1st charged and 120th charged stages, illustrating that the Co@PNCS-2 cathode could effectively catalyze the Li2O2 decomposition during cycling. The reaction mechanism for the formation-decomposition of the Li2O2 on the cathode surface was proposed (Fig. 5 a). Possible reactions are listed as Eqs. (1)–(4) [5,70]. Generally, LiO2 is formed firstly in the discharge processes, and continuous Li2O2 nucleation and growth occur afterwards. These reactions are reversible in the charge processes. The functionality of an electrocatalyst depends sensitively on the surface chemistry. Chemical adsorption is closely related to the heterogeneous catalysis. Firstly, it is possible to catalyze the reaction of solid only when it has the chemical adsorption ability of reactant molecules. In the case of complex phase catalysis, at least one reactant is chemically adsorbed on a solid surface, and such adsorption is a key step in the catalysis process. The mechanisms of the ORR and OER has been identified through the interaction energies into thermodynamic free energy figures [71,72]. For the reaction process of ORR, control factors of a high specific capacity is well manifested by the adsorption energies of the intermediates LiO2 and Li2O2. The exposed Co active sites of high binding energy provide more Li2O2 nucleation sites on the cathode surface, driving the surface growth model. When the distribution of nucleation sites is uniform and dense, the thin film of Li2O2 could be obtained via the surface model (Fig. 4d). Thus, it is an effective way to realize a high specific capacity and contribute to the reaction process of ORR by depositing uniform Li2O2 thin films on the cathode surface with strong LiO2 and Li2O2 adsorbability [73]. The XRD and SAED analysis have also revealed Co (2 0 0), Co (2 2 0) and Co (1 1 1). The surface energy was calculated by DFT computations. The Co (2 0 0), Co (2 2 0) and Co (1 1 1) crystal planes exhibit low surface energies of around −101.98, −98.06 and −106.10 eV, respectively. Therefore, Co (1 1 1) crystal plane exhibits the lowest surface energy, and thus the most stable and the easiest to be exposed. Therefore, the binding energies between the Co (1 1 1) plane (main exposed face) and different intermediates (LiO2 and Li2O2) were calculated by DFT computations. Graphitic-N1, Graphitic-N2, Pyridinic-N3 and Pyrrolic-N3 are accepted to be the main varieties of in-plane N configurations in the lattice of the N-doped carbon materials (Fig. S5), and their binding energies are also included for comparison. (1) O 2 + e - ↔ O 2 - (2) O 2 - + L i + ↔ L i O 2 (3) 2LiO2 ↔ Li2O2 + O2 (4) LiO2 + Li+ + e− ↔ Li2O2 Graphitic-N1 and Graphitic-N2 exhibit low binding energies of around −0.03 and −0.06 eV to LiO2 monomer, respectively (Fig. 5b). These are actually Van der Waals interactions, evidenced by the corresponding binding models (Fig. 5(c and d)). LiO2 monomer could be combined with Pyridinic-N and Pyrrolic-N sites on their surface (Fig. 5(e and f)), resulting in binding energies of −2.16 and −1.87 eV, respectively. The bonds of the LiO2 monomer were broken down and linked with the Co (1 1 1) plane (Fig. 5g), showing the strongest binding energy of −6.59 eV among all the active sites on the surface of the Co@PNCS catalyst. Binding energy trend and the corresponding binding models between active sites and Li2O2 monomer are very similar to those between active sites and LiO2 monomer (Fig. S6). The Co nanoparticles exhibit more superior capture capability to Li2O2 (−6.04 eV for Co(1 1 1)) than that of N active sites (−1.93 eV for Pyrrolic-N3 and −2.33 eV for Pyridinic-N3). These exposed Co nanoparticles demonstrate the binding strengths of Li2O2 on Co (1 1 1), which are sufficiently strong for the Li2O2 deposition. Li2O2 particles tend to be on the surfaces of N-carbon cathodes in the discharged stage, owing to the weak interactions between N-carbon catalysts and discharge products [68]. In contrast, stronger binding interactions between Co@PNCS catalysts and discharge products induce the formation of film-like Li2O2 products (Fig. 4d). Therefore, the DFT computation results, together with the experimental data, provide the convincing evidence for the superior electrocatalytic performance of the Co@PNCS catalysts. 4 Conclusion In summary, Co@PNCS composites were synthesized via a one-pot pyrolysis route and tested as highly efficient cathode electrocatalysts for replacing noble metal counterparts for rechargeable Li-oxygen batteries. Co nanoparticles were observed to be dispersed on the crumpled carbon nanosheets to form the hierarchical structure. This unique structure and homogeneous introduction of metallic Co and N atoms in the catalysts offered not only abundant active sites for facilitating the OER and ORR, but also sufficient space for storing the Li2O2 product, resulting in a superior catalytic activity. Owing to the N doping activation for the carbon nanosheets, the Li-oxygen battery with PNCS cathode performed a favorable discharge capacity of 5730 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and was recharged for around 49 cycles with a fixed capacity of 600 mAh g−1. In contrast, the Co@PNCS cathode reveals a higher discharge capacity of 11,329 mAh g−1, with an extended cycle life of more than 120 cycles. The hierarchical porous structure of Co@PNCS-2 provided suitable catalytic sites and facilitated mass transport in the electrode. DFT calculations indicated that the binding interaction between the discharge product and Co (1 1 1) plane was much stronger than that between the discharge product and the N active sites, leading to an improved electrocatalyst performance. We believed that the developed Co@PNCS composites pave a new method towards reasonable design of excellent catalysts as the highly efficient and durable cathodes for Li-O2 batteries to be deployed in the real-world. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt (Co) nanoparticles anchored porous N-doped carbon nanosheets (Co@PNCS) were fabricated using a facile one-pot pyrolysis route and tested as high-performance cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries. The hierarchical structure was made of cobalt nanoparticles distributed in the crumpled porous carbon nanosheets. Uniformly distributed and exposed cobalt nanoparticles in the PNCS exhibited a higher electrocatalytic activity compared to Co nanoparticles anchored nitrogen-carbon materials (Co-N-C). Density function theory (DFT) calculations based on the interfacial model demonstrated that the active Co sites exhibited a more stable binding ability to discharge Li2O2 products than that of the active N sites, and Li2O2 could be reversibly formed and decomposed during cycling. Owing to optimal loadings of Co nanoparticles (16.03 wt%), the Co@PNCS-2 cathode exhibited a high specific capacity of 11,329 mAh g−1 and extended cycling life of 120 cycles, highlighting the great potential as cathode catalysts for Li-O2 batteries.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient cobalt nanoparticles anchored porous N-doped carbon nanosheets electrocatalysts for Li-O2 batteries
